title: Extending Homemade Coffee Syrup Shelf Life

items.name: Sterilize equipment
items.details: Boil glass bottles and lids for 10 minutes, or wash in very hot soapy water and rinse thoroughly.

items.name: High sugar concentration
items.details: Use a 2:1 ratio of sugar to water to discourage microbial growth.

items.name: Natural preservatives
items.details: Add citric acid or lemon juice to lower pH and inhibit bacteria.

items.name: Commercial preservatives
items.details: Optionally use potassium sorbate or sodium benzoate.

items.name: Airtight containers
items.details: Use sterilized, airtight glass bottles or jars to minimize air exposure.

items.name: Refrigerate
items.details: Store in the refrigerator; most syrups last 2-4 weeks in the fridge.

items.name: Avoid contamination
items.details: Use a clean utensil every time; avoid dipping directly from the bottle.

items.name: Pasteurization
items.details: Heat finished syrup to 185 degrees F (85 degrees C) without boiling, then bottle hot in sterilized containers.

items.name: Monitor for spoilage
items.details: Watch for changes in smell, taste, or appearance (cloudiness, mold).

notes: If selling at a farmers market in Texas, syrups must be shelf-stable under the Texas Cottage Food Law. Lower pH to below 4.6 using citric acid, lemon juice, or vinegar. Required labeling includes product name, ingredients list, net weight/volume, allergen warnings, your name/address, and the statement: 'This food is made in a home kitchen and is not inspected by the Department of State Health Services or a local health department.' No food handler's license required in Texas, but a food safety course is recommended. A Sales Tax Permit from the Texas Comptroller is needed for taxable items.
